awd_titl_txt: Synthetic Mechanism for Semiconductor Nanocrystals and Implications for their Single Particle Photophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Todd D. Krauss of the University of Rochester is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry to understand the fundamental mechanism behind the chemical synthesis of cadmium selenide (CdSe) quantum dots (QDs) and to characterize the relationship between QD surface chemistry and photophysical properties using state-of-the-art spectroscopic and microscopic techniques. It is expected that the relationship between surface chemistry, surface trapped charge, and photoluminescence properties for individual CdSe QDs will be determined.
 
Despite over three decades of research, the fundamental chemical mechanism governing the synthesis of semiconductor QDs remains unknown. As a result of this research, rational procedures for the synthesis of QDs may be developed that are fundamentally scalable by several orders of magnitude to industrial scales, and that take place under much lower temperatures compatible with current chemical manufacturing. Large-scale synthesis of semiconductor QDs, especially those with bright and stable photoluminescence, may find broad use in biology, quantum optics, and optoelectronics. The proposed research also provides for the education and training of the next generation of physical chemists, inclusive of women and underrepresented minorities. Students supported by this project will organize and direct outreach and educational efforts in the local community through the Adopt-a-School program with the Rochester city school district, and participate in select "NanoDays" events at the Rochester Museum and Science Center.

Project Outcomes

Todd D. Krauss CHE-1307254

 

Tiny, crystalline molecules of semiconductor, called semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) have captured the interests of scientists for over three decades. While their physical properties have seen much interest in the scientific literature, the chemistry responsible for the synthesis of these QDs is much less understood. In fact, one of the major difficulties in commercializing QDs on the large scale is that many common syntheses are not generally reproducible, which arises from a lack of understanding of how chemical reaction precursors react to form the QDs. In this project we studied the fundamental reaction mechanism for the formation of CdSe QDs, representing a large class of QD materials. We have determined that no less than three separate mechanisms contribute to the formation of the first CdSe bonds in the nanoparticle. The dominant mechanism involves a breakdown of the selenium organic molecule precursor and the formation of hydrogen selenide gas, which ironically mimics the way scientists made CdSe QDs decades ago. In a related outcome, we have discovered reaction conditions for PbS and PbSe QDs that enable these reactions to go to thermodynamic completion. This means that final QD size is not related to the time the reaction is running.  Rather, QD size is related to thermodynamic properties of the chemical precursors. This key technical advance allows us to scale up these reactions significantly with little to no degradation in QD quality.  The broader impact of these findings is that a directed manipulation of these reactive intermediate species may lead to more controlled syntheses with improved reproducibility and thus accelerate the use of QDs in applications such as solar cells or solid state lighting.

 

In a second outcome, we made significant progress in understanding the doping of CdSe nanocrystal QDs with a small amount of silver ions per QD. Using advanced experimental techniques, we found that adding the silver ions tends to shift the average charge per QD negative by a very small amount, on the order of one electron. Unexpectedly, we found that as the density of silver ion per QD is varied, the average charge per doped QD tracks exceptionally well the fluorescence efficiency of the QD. We have a working theoretical model for how the silver ions affect QD fluorescence properties, and for why the addition of the a few silver ions to the nanoparticle causes the QDs to acquire a permanent negative charge.  The broader impact of this work concerns applications of QDs in photonic devices. Doping of silicon with other atoms is what is fundamentally responsible for the fabrication of integrated circuits, which has revolutionized modern society. By understanding how to dope QDs with small amounts of positive or negative ions, it may be possible to create integrated circuits using inexpensive, chemical processing technology, and on the extremely small scale.
